qas.question: What will happen to the materials when a board gets wet or is in a humid area?
If materials absorb moisture and then are heated enough to vaporize the water, the board might show delamination or what other type of damage?
What percentage absorption do F-4 epoxies have?
What's the approximate relative dielectric constant of most materials in circuit boards?
What material has an absorption rate of only 0.01%?
Teflon has a high absorption rate of what?
What suffers from low water absorption?
Repelled water can lead to what?
Careful barking of the substrates may be what?

context: <a0_0>Moisture absorption<a0_0/> occurs when the material is exposed to high humidity or water. Both <b5_0>the resin and the reinforcement<b5_0/> may absorb water; water may be also soaked by capillary forces through voids in the materials and along the reinforcement. Epoxies of the FR-4 materials aren't too susceptible, with absorption of only <a2_0>0.15%<a2_0/>. <a4_0>Teflon<a4_0/> has very low absorption of <b6_0>0.01%<b6_0/>. <b7_0>Polyimides and cyanate esters<b7_0/>, on the other side, suffer from high water absorption. Absorbed water can lead to <b8_0>significant degradation of key parameters<b8_0/>; it impairs tracking resistance, breakdown voltage, and dielectric parameters. Relative dielectric constant of water is about 73, compared to about <a3_0>4<a3_0/> for common circuitboard materials. Absorbed moisture can also vaporize on heating and cause <a1_0>cracking<a1_0/> and delamination, the same effect responsible for "popcorning" damage on wet packaging of electronic parts. Careful baking of the substrates may be <b9_0>required<b9_0/>.
